item.title: Create Deployments and Register as Microservices
item.description:
This section describes how to create a deployment and register it as a microservice.

Spring Cloud microservice instances are managed through Kubernetes deployments, with the pod replicas of the deployment being the instances of the microservice.

Prerequisites

  • KubeSphere Spring Cloud should have been installed and enabled.

  • You should join a project and have the Spring Cloud Microservices Management permission within the project. For more information, refer to "Project Members" and "Project Roles".

  • The application in the container image used to create the deployment must conform to the Nacos specification. For more information, see the Nacos Documentation.

item.title: View Microservice List
item.description:
This section describes how to view the microservice list.

Prerequisites

  • KubeSphere Spring Cloud should have been installed and enabled.

  • You should join a project and have the Spring Cloud Microservices Viewing permission within the project. For more information, refer to "Project Members" and "Project Roles".

Steps

  1. Log in to the KubeSphere web console with a user who has the Spring Cloud Microservices Viewing permission, and access your project.

  2. Click Spring Cloud > Microservices in the left navigation pane.

    • The service registry displays the address of the service registry, the number of microservices, the number of microservice instances, and the number of healthy instances.

    • The microservice list displays the number of instances, the number of healthy instances for each microservice, and whether the current microservice has triggered the health protection mechanism.

      Note

      • To prevent excessive instances from being unhealthy, leading to all traffic being directed to healthy instances and causing traffic pressure that overwhelms the healthy instances, resulting in a cascading effect, Nacos supports setting a health protection threshold. When the proportion of healthy instances to the total number of instances of a microservice is less than this value, regardless of the health status of the instances, that instance will be returned to the client.

      • The default health protection threshold for KubeSphere is 0, meaning the health protection mechanism is not used by default. You can refer to the Nacos Documentation to set the health protection threshold for Nacos.

item.title: Edit Microservice Instance Weight
item.description:
This section describes how to edit the microservice instance weight.

The weight of a microservice instance is used to determine the traffic distribution of the microservice instance. Traffic sent to the microservice will be distributed to microservice instances based on their weights.

Prerequisites

  • KubeSphere Spring Cloud should have been installed and enabled.

  • You should join a project and have the Spring Cloud Microservices Management permission within the project. For more information, refer to "Project Members" and "Project Roles".

item.title: Take Microservice Instances Offline and Online
item.description:
This section describes how to take microservice instances offline and online. After a microservice instance is offline, it will no longer receive business traffic.

Prerequisites

  • KubeSphere Spring Cloud should have been installed and enabled.

  • You should join a project and have the Spring Cloud Microservices Management permission within the project. For more information, refer to "Project Members" and "Project Roles".

Steps

  1. Log in to the KubeSphere web console with a user who has the Spring Cloud Microservices Management permission, and access your project.

  2. Click Spring Cloud > Microservices in the left navigation pane.

  3. Click on the right side of the microservice to open the microservice instance list.

  4. Click on the right side of the microservice instance you want to operate, and then select Take Offline from the drop-down list.

  5. Click on the right side of the offline microservice instance, and then select Take Online from the drop-down list to bring the microservice back online.
